user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
6. Starting with instruction-following data can limit learning.

While Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) can help a model start, too much of it makes it harder for the model to learn to think during RL.

It's because SFT teaches the model to imitate answers, not to explore and reason. https://t.co/dgmjpVWHJq

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
5. Zero RL really works — it's not just reordering answers.

Models trained with zero RL improved accuracy by 10–30% https://t.co/Hw7dQkL09X

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
4. The difficulty of training tasks needs to match the model.

If the training problems are too hard or too easy for a model, it won’t learn effectively.

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
3. Forcing answers to follow strict formats can backfire.

Requiring models to, for example, always put the final answer in a box sounds useful — but for models that aren't good at following rules yet, this actually hurts performance and makes them "overthink."

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
2. Smaller models can show signs of deeper thinking.

• Small models like Qwen-0.5B mainly improved in Subgoal Setting
• Medium Models like Llama3-8B and DeepSeek-Math-7B started verifying their own answers more often, which is a sign of the “aha moment”.
• Mistral-24B showed https://t.co/vi2YoQXdO3

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
1. Longer answers don’t always mean smarter reasoning

In many models, like those in the Qwen2.5 family, responses got longer during training — but they didn’t actually get better at reflecting or checking their work.

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
About the experiment:

The researchers trained a variety of models, both big and small, using the same simple approach:

- Giving rewards based on whether the model answered correctly on math datasets (GSM8K and MATH).
- Using RL method, called GRPO.

Key findings:

user.name: Ksenia Se
user.description: • mom to 1 girl and 4 boys • building @TheTuringPost. As one of the readers put it: “Always scientifically minded, low hype”. Machine learning-AI-Business-Life

fullText:
Unveiling more secrets about zero RL training and "aha moments" 👇

DeepSeek-R1 showed that zero RL training without extra instructions can lead to:

• “aha moments” from self-reflection
• deeper reasoning behaviors

But this was mostly tested on large or Qwen2.5 models. https://t.co/hLoNoXKVO8

user.name: Shital Shah
user.description: Mostly research and code. If universe is an optimizer, what is its loss function? All opinions are my own.

fullText:
